The other day, I was forced to attend an amateur showing of Dickens "A Christmas Carol."  The production was  well executed, the stagecraft was excellent, and the scenery  was first rate.  I've seen the Dickens classic so many times, I either just nod off, daydream, or try to improve my mind.  

During the show, I started to think of how the author, Charles Dickens, really hated capitalists and was a socialist at heart.  He portrayed Ebeneezer Scrooge as the protypical capitalist of the day, but his real "sin" was that he was a miser, only interested in his self,mistreating everyone. The fact that Scrooge  had a bad attitude and dour personality did not work in his favor and was a great device used by Dickens to generate hatred for capitalists and the rich in general...  

This got me thinking on many levels.  For one thing, Scrooge was a businessman who earned his money fair and square. He cheated nobody and expected his contracts and debts to be paid as per any previous agreements, Scrooge ran a tight ship, to the point of being called miserly. He was a demanding employeer of his clerk Mr. Cratchit, who accepted the employment contract with Mr. Scrooge with good cheer.  Much has been said and written about the evil Mr Scrooge, his name has become part of the lexicon of the definition of an evil capitalist. Even the people in the neighborhood made disparaging remarks about Scrooge, and this mistreatment and lackof respect added to his dour personality. 

There was no evil to Mr Scrooge, and his unfavorable treatment was a literary device, a populist reaction by the left, the socialists who portray all rich as greedy, evil people who allow people to suffer while they live rich, extravagant lives..  As I said before, Mr Scrooge had an employment contract with his clerk, Mr. Cratchit who was a man of good cheer.  Cratchit's wife constantly complained that Scrooge was an old miser with a flinty heart of stone.  She neglected to mention that Mr. Cratchit was free to seek employment elsewhere if his working conditions were so bad, but this aspect and so many others were left out by Dickens.. 

 As for Scrooge's miserly description, some would call his miserliness thrift, which is an esteemed Franklinian virtue..  In fact, being a miser is not one of the seven deadly sins, while gluttony is, so Scrooge was unfairly judged..  Part of the play cast Scrooge in a bad light for refusing to give to charity and telling beggars to "Bugger off.".  It seems to me that a man can do whatever he wants to with his money and charity is not the virtue the popular culture demands.  A rich man is entitled to spend his money any he pleases, just as a poor person is.. Scrooge was not required to spend his money on charity to meet the approval of his inferiors..  In fact, Mr Scrooge's self interest, his sense of business, tidyness,, and attention to detail is the real virtuous behavior in Dickens tale.. 

 Much ado was made about Scrooge's disdain for Christmas, and he was cast in an extremely sour, almost evil mode.  To the best of my knowledge, there is no law that requires one to be full of cheer, false or not, during the Christian holiday seasons,  In fact, a majority of the population of the world does not celebrate these holidays, holidays that are descended from pagan rituals anyways..

 Scrooge's refusal to  participate in a festive dinner with his nephew and wife was his business and he certainly didn't deserve the ridicule heaped upon him by the women folk, nor was he required to offer an explaination or apology..  He was merely excercising his freedom to do what he wanted, and if he chose not to celebrate Christmas, that was his natural, god given right.  During Scrooge's pre ghost phase, he was a hard nosed flinty business man, albeit a bit ill mannered.  There is no law against being ill mannered, dour, maean, or miserly. .  Scrooge was free to do whatever he wanted, with no worries what society would think as long as he behaved within the law and remaining scandal free. 

 

Every good story likes to make a case of human redemption, a change from self interest to the interest and service of the collective. In popular culture, rich are inherently evil, their gains ill gotten off the backs of workers, and the poor always triumph over the rich.   Dickens masterfully pulled this off when he had three ghosts visit Scrooge on Christmas Eve to scare the hell out of him and change his evil ways.  His powerful scare tactics caused Mr Scrooge to abandon his own self interest, abandon his personal freedom for the good of society, destroy the profitability of his business, and spend his hard earned wealth on charity to repent for his earlier miserliness.  

 

The messages Dickens made in a Christmas Carol were very clear.  Productive people must give to the more deserving poor to be considered worthy, rich people are not happy due to guilt, producers must abandon self interest in order to satisfy the needs of others in a society who don't work as hard, businessmen must run their personal business for the sole benefit of their employees, conversely to the detriment of the stockholders. And finally one must give exorbant sums to the poor, provide medical care for the employees, and give retroactive raises to allegedly underpaid employees.  Benevolence is not a virtue in this world, it is a requirement,.  Scrooge was manipulated into this transformation by the three ghosts creating immense guilt and fear, and by the end of the story Mr Scrooge was more concerned with what people thought of him, his personal image, than the real work of creating profits, creating jobs, growing a business, and contributing to the general business climate.

 

At the end of the story Mr. Scrooge was a transformed man.  He was happy, benevolent, highly thought of, giving,almost giddy, much like a person who has had a drink or ten. A good case could be made that he was a better man, but  what he lost was the real tragedy.  Scrooge lost his indendence, his freedom, became dependent not on profits, but on the opinions of others. He was required to give money away, raised expectations of others, and caused economic imbalance by changing the market pay scale of employees in his business.  In a way, Scrooge's new found largesse probably was bad for the economy as a whole.a la theories of Hazlitt.  On another note, happiness tends to be fleeting much like health and I suspect that with Mr Scrooge, old habits die hard..  

 

When the curtain closed, everyone was cheering.  I felt a bit of sadness, as here's another story of poverty trumps wealth, rich is evil while poor is good, and  being a second hander is more important than being a real, virtuous free man, In the end, Mr. Scrooge was the real loser and the real story was the transformationn of a rich, productive man.into a welfare state.

Dear Cecil:

I have three baseball questions, one technical, one historical, and one theoretical. (1) The record books credit about a dozen players with unassisted triple plays. How, exactly, is this done? (2) Has any team ever made nine double plays or more in a game? (3) Which is more elegant, a perfect game accomplished in 27 pitches, each batter hitting into an out, or one accomplished in 81 strikes, giving the position players nothing to do at all? (Warning: Roger Angell himself refused to answer this question.) --Peter D., Chicago

Cecil replies:

Roger is a good fellow, Pete, but when it comes to fine moral judgments, you'd best stick with Unca Cecil. Let's take your questions in order:

(1) In your "typical" unassisted triple play (there have been only eight or so in major league history), you've got men on first and second. The batter hits a hard shot to either (a) the shortstop or second baseman, who catches it to put out the batter, touches second, retiring the lead runner, and then tags out the runner arriving from first, or (b) the first baseman, who tags out the first base runner and then runs to second before the lead runner can return.

One of the classic unassisted triple plays (and the only one ever to occur during a World Series) happened in 1920, in the fifth game between the Cleveland Indians and the Brooklyn Robins (Brooklyn used this wimpy nickname during the time the team was coached by Wilbert Robinson). Cleveland was leading when Pete Kilduff and Otto Miller reached base safely to open the fifth for Brooklyn. Clarence Mitchell then drove to right. The immortal Bill Wambsganss, the Cleveland second baseman, made a leaping catch, stepped on second before Kilduff could get back, then tagged the startled Miller. Other notable events during the 1920 Series included the first grand-slam homer and the first homer by a pitcher in Series history. (Cleveland won the game and the Series.)

Then we have assisted triple plays such as the one on September 7, 1935, when Boston Red Sock Joe Cronin hit a line drive toward third. It bounced off the head of third baseman Odell Hale and into the hands of shortstop Bill Knickerbocker, who started a TP. I know this is a little off the track, but it just came up on my 365-Days-In-Sports desk calendar, and I couldn't stand not to use it.

(2) Not in the majors. The record is seven double plays in a game, which two teams have managed to do: Yankees, August 14, 1942, and Astros, May 4, 1969.

(3) The number of pitches thrown during a perfect game is no more relevant than the number of brush strokes used to paint the Mona Lisa. A perfect game is just that: perfect. To cavil about the minor details of such a performance is to proclaim that one has the morals of a newspaper publisher. I need say no more

I got up this morning late, around 6 AM.  I finessed the schedule to allow myself the day off.  Knowing there would be waves, I strapped one of my longboards on the roof of my car, put the wetsuit in the wetsuit bag and drove over to the south jetty.  I stopped at 7-11 and filled up my biggest cup of coffee with a ton of sugar and cream.  Driving over to the jetty, I noticed the stares of other drivers headed like ants to their work destinations.  A couple of kids looked at the board on my roof and threw me a shaka sign.  Getting over to the jetty, parking and checking out the scene, I noticed steam coming off the water, it was that cold.  The temp on the bank said 42 degrees.  I went to the john in the concession stand and quickly changed into my wetsuit, hood and booties.  A couple of locals were just going out and also a couple of guys I didn't know.  I was OK with the locals but decided to give the other guys a wide berth. The waves were pretty nice, with sets in the chest high range.  They were pretty hollow, with every other wave making a tube that held up without closing out.  The waves were ridable for about 100 yards.  My local buddies and I sat in position and shared waves, lots of waves.  The other guys we didn't know were at the next peak(we call it the hole), and pretty much stayed away from us.  I got in at least 15 good waves in an hour and a half.  I got tubed 3 times and only got closed out once.  The tide started moving, and our break started to get mushy.  Meanwhile, at the hole where the other guys were, the waves started to get really tasty.  They were breaking on both sides with perfect chest high A-frames.  We paddled over there, much to the chagrin of the non-locals who were surfing there.  They started giving us the stink-eye....I was laughing and making loud comments to my buddies about guys we've never seen before giving us the stink-eye at our break.  Nobody was messing with me and I proceeded to shred both the rights and lefts.  One of the non-locals snaked my buddy and actually called him off of the wave while he was snaking him.  My buddy held his temper and just said, don't ever do that again muthafucker.  About 2 set waves later, the same guy snaked my buddy in the same manner.  My buddy dropped off of the wave and paddled back to where we were in rotation.  I told  the other non-locals that we didn't put up with that kind of shit at our break and that they should tell their buddy to show some respect at our beach.  They ignored me.....big mistake.  I had the outside position and caught a head high wave.  I'm running down the line and one of those guys started to drop in on me.  I called him off, but he dropped in anyway.  I did a little fade, and kicked my board right into the area right behind his knee, on his right leg. We both went down and tangled in a mess of leashes and foam.  He was really wincing in pain, and I knew that he wasn't going to come after me.  The other guy that was snaking my buddy came to his aid and started cussing at me.  We told them to fuck off.  They did.  

I was getting tired by this time, so I packed it in and went home.  I had a great day of surfing, today.  I only hope that there's not a good swell on Christmas, as that will bring out all of the people who don't know how to surf that got boards for Christmas.

Whenever I go to another beach where I'm not a local, I am polite, respect the locals.  I never hog waves, and always hoot and cheer when a local snags a good ride.  I always avoid conflict, never snake waves.  If I've broken some local taboo, I offer my profuse apologies.  So far, I've never had any violence come my way in my travels.  I've surfed THE MOST LOCALIZED BREAKS ON THIS PLANET, and never had any problems.  I've always gotten my share of waves.  I've surfed the entire North Shore of Oahu from Haleiwa to Pipeline and Sunset and never had a problem.  I've surfed Windansea in La Jolla which is pretty localized and never had any problems.  I surf the Zoo they call Sebastian Inlet at least a dozen times a year and have never had any incidents with locals.

To all of the tourists, Orlando people, and everyone else.............we will welcome you to surf at our spot if you act like a human and show respect.

Happy Holidays

Aloha,

Jeff

I was playing in a huge poker game on Thursday night. It was a great table filled with both tight and loose players. There was only one player who was marginally decent, the rest were fish.  We were playing dealer's choice, and the game was running very smoothly.  I was in my passive-aggressive playing mode and really confusing the other players.  Since the games we were playing were pot limit, as soon as I built up my stack, I used it to clobber the other guys.

We finished up the game playing a little Hold-em.....I hate that game.

I was dealt Ah,Kd and was in sixth position.  I hate getting that hand, for statistical reasons I won't get into here.  Anyway, I just wanted to limp in to see the flop.  There were only 2 raises before me, so I raised and everyone saw me.  No reraising?......hmmmmm.  The flop came Ad,Kc,Qc.  I've got two high pair, enough to stay in......maybe.  The round of betting before the turn card had a couple of guys drop out, and a couple of raises. I checked into the raisers, cautiously biding my time. The turn card came and it was a As.  I had my full house and had to try to get as much money into the pot as I could.  There were only 2 other guys in the pot and I had them chasing flushes.  Both guys raised, and I checked each time.  There was no way I was going to raise that puppy and scare anyone outof the pot, especially guys who were chasing flushes.  The river card came and was a 4c.  I could automatically see that both guys made their flush.  I was glad for them.  Guy #2 bet, guy #5 raised him, and I came in and raised the entire pot.
